framework_context.description: Skepticism and Doubt is a fundamental aspect of Epistemology, specifically within the domain of the Limits of Knowledge. It explores the nature of uncertainty and the challenges in validating knowledge, which are essential for understanding how we acquire and validate knowledge.

key_concepts.name: Pyrrhonian Skepticism
key_concepts.explanation: A school of thought that questions the possibility of certain knowledge, arguing that we can't be sure of our beliefs.

key_concepts.name: Cartesian Doubt
key_concepts.explanation: A methodological approach to questioning everything one knows, as exemplified by René Descartes' 'Meditations on First Philosophy'.

key_concepts.name: Fallibilism
key_concepts.explanation: The view that all knowledge is provisional and subject to revision based on new evidence or arguments.

major_principles.name: The Agrippan Trilemma
major_principles.description: A philosophical argument that suggests there are three ways to justify beliefs: infinite regress, circular reasoning, or an arbitrary starting point.

major_principles.name: The Problem of Induction
major_principles.description: A challenge to inductive reasoning posed by David Hume, questioning whether we can justify our belief in universal laws based on past experiences.

relationships.connection: Skepticism and Doubt are central to Epistemology as they address the fundamental questions about how we acquire, validate, and understand knowledge.
Skepticism can influence Ontology by questioning the nature of reality and our understanding of existence, particularly in relation to the limits of knowledge.
Skepticism can inform Cognitive Science by examining how our cognitive biases and limitations affect our perception of reality and our ability to generate knowledge.
Skepticism impacts Philosophy of Science by challenging the foundations and methods of scientific inquiry, particularly in terms of empirical evidence and theoretical frameworks.

implications.description: Skepticism and Doubt have broader implications for knowledge organization by highlighting the provisional nature of all knowledge. This encourages continuous inquiry, critical thinking, and a holistic approach to understanding complex problems.
